description: Remote sensing dataset for detecting diseased trees (Japanese oak wilt and Japanese pine wilt) in Quickbird satellite imagery. Contains spectral and texture features from image segments with highly imbalanced classes.

feature_description.GLCM_pan: Gray Level Co-occurrence Matrix texture feature from panchromatic band
feature_description.Mean_Green: Mean value of green band pixels within segment
feature_description.Mean_Red: Mean value of red band pixels within segment
feature_description.Mean_NIR: Mean value of near-infrared band pixels within segment
feature_description.SD_pan: Standard deviation of panchromatic band within segment

use_case: Forest health monitoring, disease detection in vegetation, precision forestry, environmental conservation, satellite image analysis

dataset_splits.note: Testing set from stratified random sample with segmentation scale 15

data_collection: Image segments generated by segmenting pansharpened Quickbird imagery. Segments contain both spectral information from multispectral bands and texture information from panchromatic band.
preprocessing: Image segmentation applied to create homogeneous regions, feature extraction from each segment including spectral means and texture metrics
performance_considerations: Extreme class imbalance requires specialized techniques (SMOTE, cost-sensitive learning, anomaly detection approaches)
advantages: Real-world remote sensing application, high-quality satellite data, important environmental monitoring use case
challenges: Severe class imbalance (98.5% vs 1.5%), small number of positive examples, generalization to other forest types/diseases
research_applications: Imbalanced classification, remote sensing analysis, environmental monitoring, precision agriculture/forestry
ethical_considerations: Environmental conservation application, potential for automated forest health monitoring to support sustainability efforts
